newsitem.title: EGYPT: Eastern Company forcasts higher dividend.
newsitem.headline: Eastern Company forcasts higher dividend.

text.p: Monopoly cigarette manufacturer Eastern Company, on the basis of promising first-half results, expects to pay out a cash dividend of 5.00 pounds a share for the financial year 1996/7, its parent company said on Thursday.
The dividend in the previous two years was 4.00 pounds a share.

The Holding Company for Mining and Refractories, which retains a major holding in Eastern, said that in the first half of the financial year (July-December 1996) Eastern made profits for distribution of 87.939 million pounds ($26 million), compared with 145.820 million in the whole of 1995/6.
Earlier this month Eastern Company said it made net profits of 67.9 million in the first half of the year, against 43.2 million in the first half of 1995/6.
An executive at Eastern Company said on Thursday that the accountants had since moved 20 million pounds from the "provisions" category into the profits account.
Shareholders' funds at the end of the six-month period were worth 665.035 million pounds, 26.60 pounds for each of the 25 million shares, against 572.605 million at the end of June 1996.
The shares closed on the Egyptian stock exchange on Wednesday at 87.00 pounds.
Here are the six-month results, compared with results for all of the year 1995/6 (figures in milions of pounds):
